part.title: Introduction
part.para: Gestaltlupe is a scientific tool to render tomographic functions. A tomographic function T(p) (p is a point p=(x,y,z) in R^3) returns either true or false. The rendering interpreted this as formula description of an arbitrary object in the 3D space. This means: T(p)=true, if and only if p is inside the object.

Double click on Gestaltlupe_1_0_2.exe , choose Tab file, load an sample project and press the button “preview” to get after a short time a small picture of the given 3D object, or press "start" to render a bitmap in full resolution.

part.title: Install
part.para:
Gestaltlupe is available at GitHub at:
http://github.com/trafassel/Gestaltlupe
The corresponding Version 1.0.2, which is documented here, can be found at:
http://github.com/trafassel/Gestaltlupe/blob/master/bin/Gestaltlupe_1_0_2.exe
On this page you have to click “raw” to get the binary. But the recommended way to work with Gestaltlupe is to download the full archive file (the big “Download” button at http://github.com/trafassel/Gestaltlupe ). The archive contains the binaries and sample projects with the corresponding formulas.

chapter.title: Windows
chapter.para: Gestaltlupe is developed and tested with WindowsXP and Windows7. It is a native .NET 2.0 application.

chapter.title: Linux
chapter.para: To run Gestaltlupe on a Linux system, you have to install the mono package (http://www.mono-project.com/Main_Page ). It is tested on a Ubuntu Hardy Heron 8.04.3 LTS. It runs without problems, but looks more ugly than the windows version (Yes, that is possible).

chapter.title: Mac OSX
chapter.para: It is tested on a Mac OSX 10.6. with Mono 2.8 . It can produce some nice pictures, but working is a pain, because some windows forms are not redrawn properly (Gestaltlupe is compatible to the Windows.Forms library 2.0).

part.title: Interface Description
part.para: After its first start, Gestaltlupe presents the following interface.
If you click on the left square in the bottom frame, you get a small overview of the defined scene.
If the view looks OK, you can click on Preview to get a greater picture. The result ist presented in the output window.
The picture is saved automatic. The corresponding path is given at the top of the output window.
The final rendering starts after click on the button Start.
Are you satisfied with the result? Not, oh, ...
If you want to improve the quality of the rendering result, you have the read the chapter Rendering.
Or perhaps you want to see, what is inside the tunnel or you want to rotate and zoom the whole object. The chapter Navigation describes, how to navigate in the virtual 3D space.
I understand. You favourite formula is another fractal, and you want to have some colours. Then you have to read the chapter Formula.
